sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: You're watching Euronews Tonight. I'm Mariam Zahidi and these are the headlines this hour.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Another day of trying to get people out of the besieged city of Mariupol as reports say Russian forces have stepped up attacks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Hungary denies reports that it has received prior warning about Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: invasion of Ukraine. President Biden calls the leaked document that shows the U.S. Supreme Court may overturn abortion rights radical and says it puts a whole range of rights in jeopardy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And Liverpool take on Villareal in the first of the Champions League semi-final second legs tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Good evening. Efforts to evacuate civilians from Ukraine's besieged port city of Mariupol

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: are ongoing, despite reports that Russian forces have stepped up attacks in the area.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Ukrainian troops holed up in the Avostal steelworks plant claim Moscow is attacking the site with all kinds of weapons in an attempt to capture the last Ukrainian stronghold in the city. That's despite reports that many civilians including dozens of children remain trapped in a network of tunnels that run below the plant. Mariupol's mayor says that 100,000 civilians are still living in the city which is now occupied by Russian forces. The UN and Red Cross have confirmed that over a hundred civilians have been successfully evacuated from Mariupol.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The ICRC says a convoy of buses, ambulances and private vehicles arrived in the city of Zafariša on Tuesday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Families, young children and the wounded were among those greeted by aid workers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Some described the horrors they witnessed at the hands of Russian forces.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Some described the horrors they witnessed at the hands of Russian forces.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We are so tired and I can't talk. I'm not feeling well after so many attacks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And two days on the road.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: They started bombing us from one side and the other, and we found ourselves in the middle.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: And that was it. Every day and night, non-stop.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Completely burnt, completely destroyed by bombing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Why this war? Who needs this war?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: My neighbours have died, the people who I was born with and grew up with.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: I lived in their house. Do you understand how serious it is?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Children died, dead bodies are scattered in the streets and no one went there to remove them.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The head of the Red Cross in Ukraine spoke about the psychological trauma

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: experienced by those trapped underground in the Azosol plant.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Take a look.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Spending so many days and nights in a bunker without being able to go out, fearing that your life may end within a second. I can just imagine the traumatized, how people can be traumatized. And you have seen there were young kids there, there were women, there were old people. So maybe the visible The visible suffering is not something that we can see, or the invisible suffering is much bigger than what we can see when we see them like that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And as revelations of suffering continue to emerge, Prime Minister Boris Johnson addressed the Ukraine parliament,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: telling lawmakers that Ukraine will win in the war against Russia. Johnson praised the Ukrainian people's courage and resilience in the face of Russian aggression. Richard Cady reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson told Ukraine's MPs that their country has achieved the greatest feat of arms of the 21st century by repelling Russia's attempts to capture Kyiv.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: rate his feet of arms of the 21st century by repelling Russia's attempts to capture Kyiv.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: He also announced a new package of military aid worth 300 million pounds.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: We will carry on supplying Ukraine alongside your other friends with weapons, with funding and humanitarian aid until we have achieved our long-term goal, have achieved our long-term goal which must be so to fortify ukraine that no one will ever dare attack you again the military aid to be sent to ukraine in the coming weeks will include electronic warfare equipment a counter battery radar system gps jammers and night vision devices and night vision devices.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: It's a conflict that has no moral ambiguities or grey areas.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: This is about the right of Ukrainians to protect themselves against Putin's violent and murderous aggression.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: It's about Ukraine's right to independence and national self-determination against Putin's deranged imperialist revanchism.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Speaking to Ukraine's parliament in Kyiv, Johnson said the West had been too slow to grasp what was really happening when Russia seized Crimea in 2014.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And that mistake must not happen again.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Richard Cady, Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The EU is expected to finalise its sixth round of sanctions that will include a long-called-for

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: ban on Russian oil and gas.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The proposal put forward by Commission President Ursula von der Leyen hasn't been welcomed by all member states, particularly the ones that rely most heavily on Russian energy supplies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: For more, let's now cross over to Strasbourg and to Shona Murray.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So, Shona, are we anywhere nearer to knowing when this latest sanctions package will be announced?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And what are the details, perhaps, on the oil phase-out?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Well, we'll actually know within, I suppose, the next 12 hours.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: The College of Commissioners will sign off on that proposal this evening, probably the next couple of hours.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And as we know, there will be an oil embargo, oil sanctions of some description.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: That will be sent to the EU member states tomorrow for discussion by EU ambassadors.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: All 27 member states have to agree before this package is proposed and actually is triggered.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: So it's a bit of a way to go yet, but I know that the commissioner will be signing off on it shortly.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: But I'm joined now by Rio Teres, who's an Estonian MEP and a former general in the Estonian army.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Rio, first of all, finally we're getting to the point where there's oil embargoes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: How much will that affect the Russian military?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Well, I think the Russian war in Ukraine is financed by European countries right now, and the full embargo of oil and gas is absolutely necessary, and the oil is one step.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: But I would call the heads of state to really put more sanctions because the gas is as important as the oil.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: But it will hurt, for sure, the Russian economy because to close down the oil rigs and to stop drilling, it is almost impossible to start it again.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: So it will really hurt the economy, and I think it is a good thing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And I called the ambassadors to call for sanctions against the heads of state to call Putin, because I think that is ridiculous that we give Putin the advantage to talk to heads of state of European Union, and at the same time he would never lift his phone and call it back.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So that's my call.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: You believe that there should be an end to phone calls by Charles Michel, President of the European Council, or Emmanuel Macron because it's getting nowhere?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Absolutely, we see it's ridiculous.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And I really would see Putin lifting the phone and trying to talk to the heads of state of European countries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: So the dialogue has been fruitless so far.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: It needs to be.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: I don't see any use of it. Talk to me about the military assessment here. Obviously we've seen a huge focus by the Russian military on Mariupol again. How do you assess what's happening at the moment? Well I still see that the Russian forces are sick. They are not advancing anywhere really. They have tried to have a big attack against Izum or in the area of Izium.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: They have been pushed out of Kharkov.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: They have not gained any territory, really, very few.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So I don't see that the big offensive is successful, and I don't see reserves.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So I think now we should think and look what is happening to Russian army in the coming days.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So when you say you don't see reserves, are you saying that you have a depleted army here? If they are not able to succeed with their offensive that means they didn't have enough resources and I think it's it talks about they don't have enough weapons or they don't have enough people or both. So what should be the next phase then for the Ukrainian army to try to drive Russia out? Wait wait until their armament, which is promised by the European countries and others, like-minded nations to Ukraine, arrives in Ukraine and then to start to gain their territory back.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: So you're confident with how the Ukrainian army is managing this?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Well, I really do hope that their weaponry reaches the front line, goes to the east. I know Russians try to make it impossible by attacking the transport and logistic lines, but I see that that is the way.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: OK, Vyotiris, thank you very much for joining us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: OK, Shona, thanks for the latest updates from the Strasbourg Plenary. Thank you so much. OK, well, protests are growing across the US

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: after a leaked Supreme Court document revealed millions of women could lose their legal right to abortion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: A draft paper published by Politico says the top court could be poised to overturn the 1973 decision in Robes as Wade that legalised abortion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: A decision to strike down the ruling would allow individual states to ban access to the procedure. President Biden has slammed what he called the radical draft, saying it puts a whole range of rights at risk. Well, let's now cross over to our reporter, Ray Suarez, who's in Washington, D.C. Ray, always good to see you. So, President Biden has released this really strong statement condemning the move by the Supreme Court. Now, if this document is what it says, and it's true, but can he really do anything here to overturn this potential move?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: RAY SUAREZ, Former U.S. Secretary of State for the United States of America, What he can do with his Democratic allies on Capitol Hill here in Washington is draft a law that would protect the rights that are enshrined in the Roe v. Wade decision from the early 70s.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The Supreme Court only becomes a big issue in this country when the legislature doesn't act.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The court moves into a vacuum created by the absence of laws and says, here's what the existing laws mean.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Joe Biden is calling on his allies to draft a law.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The Democrats currently control the House of Representatives.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: They control, by a sliver, the United States Senate and the White House. So, it's really ball in Democrats' court at this point to sharpen the debate as it stands in advance of November's midterm elections, a big, big battle. I don't want to minimize how difficult it would be to pass a law protecting the right to abortion, but that's really the state of play right now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: NERMEEN SHAIKH, And, Ray, the leaking of this document itself, I mean, just by itself, it's absolute dynamite. Nothing like this has ever been seen before, has it?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: RAY SUAREZ, The Washington Post, It's hard to exaggerate just how out of order this is.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Part of the power of the Supreme Court in this country comes from its mysteriousness, from the inability of the public to read or predict outcomes of cases until the court speaks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It's bound by tradition.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It's bound by being removed from the day-to-day of nasty American politics.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The court gave away a little bit of that mystery when it became a leaking institution, just like elected officials sometimes leak confidential documents and reporters get their hands on them, in this case the Web site Politico, with the bombshell of this draft opinion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Now, the opinion is not final. The final vote is not known.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But it looks like this is the strongest signal yet that Roe v. Wade, which has been at the heart of American conflict over politics in this country for half a century is about to go down.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: OK, Ray Suarez, thanks for analyzing that potential shift on abortion in the U.S. first. Thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Now, Hungary has denied media reports that it had been warned by Russia about the planned invasion

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: of Ukraine. Let's find out more from Matthew in the Cube. Matthew.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Mariam, Hungary has come under fire, even from its ownew in the cube matthew mariam hungary has come under fire even from its own allies in the european union over its stance on the war in ukraine so far budapest has voted in favor of sanctions packages against moscow but it has stood firm against any measures on russian energy imports upon which the country relies and now there there have been claims that Hungary had been aware about the invasion of Ukraine even before it began. Local media in Ukraine quoting a senior Kyiv official suggesting that not only did Hungary know about the invasion beforehand, but that Hungary had also allegedly been planning to annex Transcarpathia, a region in western Ukraine home to around 140,000 ethnic Hungarians. As you can imagine these reports generated a lot of reaction online but the Hungarian government has been quick to dismiss these allegations as fake news the prime minister spokesperson Zoltan kovacs said on Twitter that these rumors had come in retaliation after Hungary refused to send weapons to Ukraine he wrote here that while we understand that Ukraine does not welcome our decision, spreading fake news and coming up with lies will not change our position.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Of course, Marianne, this is not the first time that Hungary has clashed with Ukraine or even the European Union since Russia launched its invasion on February 24th.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: And it seems likely that these tensions are going to remain, even as the EU tries to maintain a united stance with its sanctions on Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Now on Press Freedom Day, Reporters Without Borders has released its annual World Press

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Freedom Index. Its findings show an even bigger gap in polar polarized opinions and spread of disinformation being amplified on social media jean cavalier head of eastern europe and its central asia desk at reporters without borders joins me now to discuss the report in more detail jean cavalier thanks for being with us on the program tonight so are we seeing then a deterioration of press freedom globally you list polarization and opinion media as factors. Take us through the factors and divisions that you are seeing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Yes, we've seen a global deterioration. The press freedom situation is classified as very bad in a record number of 28 countries this year out of 180. Several countries dropped in the index, like Myanmar, where the coup d'etat set press freedom back by 10 years, or in the E.U., in Greece, especially because of an resolved murder of an investigative journalist. The ranking, as you've said, also highlights the disastrous effects of news and information chaos, the effects of a globalized and unregulated online information space that encourages fake news and propaganda. Of course, the invasion of Ukraine by Russia at the end of February reflects this process as the physical conflict was preceded by a propaganda war. So let's pick up on that. You mentioned the propaganda and Russia. They've also had a crackdown on so-called fake news. So has the war in Ukraine then really eroded press freedom in Russia? And can we ever see it coming back or getting better?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Unfortunately, I doubt it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Not in the next months.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Russia is now ranked 155th out of 180 countries. It fell in the worst category of the ranking.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The press freedom situation there is now classified as very serious.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And journalists in Russia are clearly targeted by the authorities.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The vast majority of independent media have been blocked or forced to shut down.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The journalists face dreadful military censorship.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: For instance, they can be sentenced to up to 15 years in prison for spreading so-called false information about the Russian armed force.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: After what we observed recently, it's after dispatching the national independent press, the Russian authorities have embarked on a witch hunt designed to silence the few local journalists still daring to provide reporting or commentary that contradicts the propaganda about the war launched in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And the journalists who stay in their country cannot continue to work independently without a high risk of arrest.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Because of this press freedom environment of total censorship, we observe a massive exodus of Russian journalists.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Yeah, that's not a good situation there, it seems at all.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So Ukraine then, that also slips in your rankings.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Just how difficult is it for journalists who are covering this war?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Yeah, Ukraine is ranked 106th out of 180 countries this year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: is ranked 106th out of 180 countries this year. Since the invasion, the safety of journalists in the country has been more, has been threatened more than ever. They are sometimes deliberately targeted by fire, despite their press identification. Already seven reporters have been killed and 12 injured as a result of gunfire while covering the war. In the world, we count in total 25 journalists killed because of their work since the beginning of this year. So seven is huge.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Also in the occupied territories, we've seen a dreadful manhunt against journalists in Ukraine, too. So they have to disseminate the Kremlin propaganda or to be silent.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: In the Parasitia region, for instance, our sources revealed that Russian troops are compiling lists of journalists.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The soldier visits them to convince them to stick to their propaganda.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But most of the time, the journalists, the local journalists don't obey.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: So they are subjected to interrogations, to searches.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Their equipment is seized.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And in some cases, they have been taken hostage tortured and sometimes their relatives taken hostage also in total we have documented around 40 cases of violations of journalist rights okay John Cavalier thank you for outlining all of that for us you know the conditions that journalists have to work and, especially during war, is very hard indeed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Thank you so much for joining us on the programme. Thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Welcome back to Euronews tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Now, it's a massive week in European football with the Champions League semi-final second legs getting underway.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Now, tonight's game sees Liverpool travel to Villarreal with the Reds holding a 2-0 advantage from the opening leg. Sports editor Andy Rubini is here to preview this crucial tie. I know, really looking forward to this match. So Liverpool manager Jürgen Klopp, he's really told his players to play a top game tonight against Villarreal. They have this two goal buffer. What do you think his tactics are going to be tonight then?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: I don't think he'll change anything tactically speaking and that's the reason why we love Jürgen Klopp.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: He's not the type of manager to adapt to other sides. The other sides adapt to Liverpool at the moment.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: I don't think he'll be underestimating Unai Emery though. I watched them closely against Juventus, also against Bayern Munich.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: They won 1-0 this first leg against the German side and I thought they were very unlucky just to score one goal and not two or three which just goes to show that they're not just a counter-attacking side they can also attack. So I do expect a game that will be rather open tonight but you can probably score one against Liverpool maybe two I don't know but it will be so hard to to keep all their strikers at bay, Sadio Mane, Mo Salah, and if it's not the pair of them, then it will be Diaz, it could be Jota as well, all these new signings which show that Liverpool have got their recruitment spot on, they know what players to get, and that's also testament to some great work from Jürgen Klopp, he has a style of play, he knows exactly who he wants, and they can adapt and help the team, but I do expect a good game of football tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Liverpool definitely are a special team.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: That's what their fans would definitely say.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Now, UEFA, they've also announced further sanctions against Russian teams in response to, of course, the invasion of Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Talk us through what we know.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: So first up, the women's national team have been barred from competing in this summer's Euro 2022.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: This means that Portugal, who lost to Russia in the playoffs, will be able to compete in this competition, which kicks off in July. The women's national team also won't be able to qualify for next year's World Cup, which will take place in Australia and New Zealand. As for the men's national team, they had already been suspended by FIFA and UEFA until further notice which meant that they weren't able to qualify for the Qatar World Cup. They won't be able either to take part in the Nations League next season. Russia had also made a bid to host Euro 2028 and Euro 2032. At the time the UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson said that Russia's interest was beyond satire and beyond comprehension. Finally UEFA have made it clear that this bid was ineligible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Russian clubs will also be banned from UEFA competitions next season, which means no Champions League, no Europa League, no Europa Conference League.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: This means that Scotland, thanks to their coefficients ranking, will now receive a guaranteed spot in the Champions League.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Celtic seem to be the beneficiaries of this as they currently lead Rangers by six points in the standings.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Definitely strong steps being taken against Russia for the invasion of Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And, Eurabini, thank you as always.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And hopefully you'll be back tomorrow to tell us all about how Liverpool did.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: OK, well, that's it for us tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: From myself and the team, thanks for watching.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Take care. Bye-bye.
